content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

I see multiple sections of tissue on the slide, approximately eight to nine pieces. Most of the sections are pink, irregularly shaped, and show areas of hemorrhage and necrosis, which are likely fragments of the primary colorectal tumor and surrounding fatty tissue. At the bottom left, there is one distinct, ovoid, and densely basophilic (purple) tissue section, which has the classic appearance of a lymph node. My initial task would be to systematically examine this and any other potential lymph nodes for evidence of metastasis.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I am zooming into this area because it is clearly identifiable as a lymph node, the first one from the bottom left. A crucial part of staging colorectal cancer is to determine the N stage, which requires a thorough examination of all harvested lymph nodes for metastatic tumor cells. I would start my systematic review with this well-preserved lymph node. The specific zoom location is at the periphery of the node, which is a critical area to inspect as metastatic cells typically first arrive and implant in the subcapsular sinus. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see the edge of the lymph node. There is a dense population of small, round, dark-staining lymphocytes, which is characteristic of normal or reactive lymphoid tissue. At the very bottom, a thin fibrous capsule is visible, with a subcapsular sinus just above it. The lymphoid architecture in this specific field of view appears preserved. I do not see any clusters of atypical epithelial cells, glandular structures, or extensive mucin pools that would indicate metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression of this particular area is that it is benign and negative for metastasis. However, I would need to scan the entire lymph node to make a definitive conclusion.
